persona.name: Kai Amara Takahashi-Williams

occupation.title: Freelance Graphic Designer & Social Media Content Creator (Unemployed/Underemployed)
occupation.description: Kai has worked sporadically as a freelance graphic designer, creating digital illustrations, album covers, and social media graphics for local musicians, activist groups, and small businesses. Most recent paid gig was designing event flyers for a queer open mic night. Currently unemployed, applying for part-time retail and barista jobs to make ends meet. Has a portfolio website and active Instagram art account, but struggles with self-promotion and consistency due to anxiety and depressive episodes. Occasionally volunteers design skills for mutual aid projects and community zines. Has experience with Adobe Creative Suite, Canva, and basic video editing. No formal employment benefits; income is irregular and often insufficient.

education.details: Attended Columbia College Chicago for two years, majoring in Graphic Design with a minor in Media Studies. Left before completing degree due to financial constraints and mental health challenges. Completed several online courses in digital illustration, social media marketing, and video editing. High school diploma from a public magnet school in Seattle with a focus on the arts. Participated in student-run zines and the LGBTQ+ alliance.

long_term_goals: Achieve financial stability and pay off credit card debt.
Build a sustainable freelance career in arts and media, ideally working on projects that align with personal values (social justice, climate action, queer visibility).
Publish a graphic novel or webcomic exploring multiracial and queer identities.
Create a supportive online community for marginalized creatives.
Travel to Japan and Ghana to connect with family roots and document the experience through art.
Secure affordable, stable housing in a vibrant, diverse urban neighborhood.
Improve mental health and develop healthier coping mechanisms.
Adopt a rescue cat or dog when financially able.
Contribute to mutual aid and grassroots organizing in the local community.
Learn Japanese and improve conversational skills in Spanish.

style.fashion: Eclectic, gender-fluid, and highly curated. Mixes thrifted vintage pieces (oversized blazers, high-waisted trousers, 90s windbreakers) with statement sneakers and bold accessories (chunky jewelry, enamel pins, patterned scarves). Prioritizes shoes as a key element of every outfit—prefers limited-edition or artist-collab sneakers, platform boots, and vegan leather options. Enjoys layering textures and colors, often combining streetwear with elements inspired by Japanese and African diasporic fashion. Avoids overtly gendered clothing, favoring androgynous silhouettes.
style.grooming: Short, asymmetrical haircut, sometimes dyed in pastel or jewel tones. Minimal makeup, but experiments with graphic eyeliner or nail art when feeling creative. Wears subtle piercings (nose stud, multiple ear piercings).
style.speech: Speaks with a soft, slightly raspy voice. Uses a mix of urban Midwest and Pacific Northwest slang, peppered with internet lingo and occasional Japanese phrases. Tends toward informal, colloquial language, but can become articulate and passionate when discussing social issues or art. Sometimes stumbles or trails off when anxious.
style.mannerisms: Fidgets with rings or hoodie strings when nervous. Makes expressive hand gestures when excited. Maintains eye contact in small groups but avoids it in crowds. Smiles shyly when complimented, but deflects praise. Often slouches or sits cross-legged.
style.social presence: Active on Instagram, Twitter, and TikTok, curating a personal brand that blends art, activism, and daily life. Prefers online interaction to in-person networking. Attends local art shows, open mics, and protests, but often lingers at the edges rather than the center.

traits: Highly creative and imaginative, always generating new ideas for art and projects.
Deeply curious, enjoys learning about different cultures, histories, and subcultures.
Empathetic and sensitive to the emotions of others, but struggles to set boundaries.
Prone to anxiety and mood swings; can become withdrawn or irritable under stress.
Values authenticity and self-expression, resists conformity.
Impulsive, especially with spending and decision-making.
Idealistic, sometimes to the point of frustration with the status quo.
Introverted in large groups, but warm and animated with close friends.
Self-critical, often doubts own abilities and worth.
Resilient—despite setbacks, continues to pursue creative goals.
Distractible, finds it hard to maintain routines or focus on long-term tasks.
Non-confrontational, avoids direct conflict but will speak up for social justice.
Open about mental health struggles, but sometimes overshares online.
Enjoys solitude, but fears being forgotten or left out.
Playful sense of humor, uses memes and irony to cope with stress.

big_five.openness: Very high—constantly seeks new experiences, ideas, and creative outlets.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low—struggles with organization, deadlines, and follow-through.
big_five.extraversion: Low to moderate—prefers small gatherings and online interaction to large crowds.
big_five.agreeableness: High—compassionate, cooperative, and values fairness, but can be passive-aggressive when overwhelmed.
big_five.neuroticism: Very high—frequent anxiety, mood instability, and emotional sensitivity.

interests: Visual arts (digital illustration, collage, zines, street art).
DIY fashion—customizing thrifted clothes, upcycling, and sewing patches.
Sneaker culture—follows drops, reviews, and artist collaborations.
Vegan and vegetarian cooking, especially fusion recipes.
Online activism and mutual aid organizing.
Queer literature, webcomics, and graphic novels.
Indie and alternative music (lo-fi hip hop, neo-soul, bedroom pop, J-pop, Afrofuturist artists).
Anime and manga, especially works exploring identity and social issues.
Attending art shows, open mics, and underground music events.
Urban exploration—photographing street art, abandoned buildings, and cityscapes.
Streaming TV series (sci-fi, coming-of-age, and dark comedies).
Podcasts on mental health, politics, and pop culture.
Journaling and creative writing.
Participating in online fandoms and Discord communities.
Collecting enamel pins, stickers, and zines.
Sustainable living—composting, zero-waste swaps, supporting ethical brands.
Coffee shop hopping—prefers indie cafes with plant-based options and cozy atmospheres.
Board games and tabletop RPGs with friends.
Learning about family history and cultural traditions.
Practicing mindfulness and guided meditation (inconsistently).
likes: Chunky, colorful sneakers that make a statement.
Vegan leather boots and platform shoes.
Mixing patterns and textures in outfits.
Handmade jewelry and accessories from local artists.
Indie coffee shops with mismatched furniture and zines on display.
Plant-based pastries and oat milk lattes.
Late-night walks through city neighborhoods.
Rainy days spent drawing or binge-watching shows.
Collaborative art projects and zine swaps.
Queer-friendly spaces and events.
Secondhand bookstores and record shops.
Street food festivals and night markets.
Public transit—people-watching and sketching on the train.
Scented candles and incense.
Memes, shitposting, and ironic humor.
Mutual aid fundraisers and community potlucks.
Listening to music while working on art.
Window shopping for sneakers and streetwear online.
Learning new digital art techniques.
Receiving handwritten letters or postcards.
dislikes: Overly gendered or corporate fashion.
Fast fashion brands with poor labor practices.
Shoes that are uncomfortable or impractical for city walking.
Crowded, noisy bars and clubs.
Being pressured to conform to binary gender norms.
People who dismiss mental health struggles.
Gentrification and loss of local culture.
Performative activism and virtue signaling.
Overly bright, sterile environments.
Small talk with strangers.
Being misgendered or having identity invalidated.
Animal products in food or clothing.
Unsolicited advice about career or finances.
Wasting food or resources.
Corporate social media accounts pretending to be 'woke.'
Being interrupted while working on art.
Having to dress formally for events.
Long periods without creative stimulation.
Unreliable public transit.
People who don't return borrowed books or zines.

beliefs: Capitalism is inherently exploitative and unsustainable.
Worker ownership and cooperative models are preferable to corporate hierarchies.
Wealth should be redistributed to address systemic inequality.
Universal healthcare is a human right; the US system is broken and unaffordable.
Climate change is the most urgent crisis facing humanity; radical action is needed.
Social justice movements (Black Lives Matter, LGBTQ+ rights, disability justice) are essential for progress.
Intersectionality is crucial—oppression is multifaceted and interconnected.
Police and prison abolition should be seriously considered; alternatives to punitive justice are needed.
Gun control is necessary—supports closing gun show loopholes and implementing red flag laws.
Abortion should be legal in all cases; bodily autonomy is non-negotiable.
Immigrants deserve a path to legal status and dignity.
The US economy is on the wrong track; corporate interests dominate politics.
Inflation is causing severe hardship, especially for low-income people.
Healthcare costs are a major source of anxiety and financial stress.
The Supreme Court is untrustworthy and out of touch with the public.
US support for Israel is excessive and ignores Palestinian rights.
Mutual aid and grassroots organizing are more effective than top-down charity.
Queer and trans people deserve full legal and social recognition.
Cultural heritage should be celebrated, not commodified.
Art is a tool for resistance and healing.
Mental health should be destigmatized and prioritized.
Food justice and access to healthy, plant-based options are important.
Gentrification displaces marginalized communities and erases culture.
Online communities can be powerful sources of solidarity and support.
Voting is important, but not sufficient for real change.
Corporate 'wokeness' is often performative and hollow.
Personal style is a form of self-expression and resistance.
Technology should be accessible and used for collective good.
Education should be free and liberatory.
Family is chosen as much as biological.
Traditions can be reimagined to be more inclusive.
Creativity is a survival skill.
Rest is resistance in a productivity-obsessed culture.
Everyone deserves safe, affordable housing.
Language matters—pronouns, names, and labels should be respected.
Solidarity across movements is necessary for systemic change.
Hope is a discipline, not a feeling.
skills: Digital illustration (Procreate, Adobe Illustrator, Photoshop).
Graphic design for print and web (flyers, posters, social media graphics).
Basic video editing (Premiere, CapCut, TikTok).
Social media management and content creation.
Copywriting for zines, captions, and short-form content.
DIY fashion—sewing, patching, customizing clothes.
Event promotion and community organizing (online and in-person).
Basic HTML/CSS for personal website maintenance.
Photography (urban, street, and event).
Public speaking (open mics, panels, workshops—though with anxiety).
Vegan and vegetarian cooking (meal prepping, recipe adaptation).
Basic Japanese (greetings, family conversations).
Conflict mediation in online spaces.
Peer support for mental health (active listening, resource sharing).
Budgeting (though not always successful in practice).
Thrift shopping and upcycling.
Zine layout and small-batch printing.
Networking with local artists and activists.
Podcast editing (beginner level).
Mindfulness and guided meditation (self-taught).

general: Scrolls social media feeds for hours, often late at night.
Impulse buys art supplies or thrifted clothes when stressed.
Avoids checking bank account or bills until absolutely necessary.
Posts art and personal updates on Instagram, sometimes deletes later out of anxiety.
Attends protests, art shows, and community events, but often leaves early due to sensory overload.
Cooks large batches of vegan chili or curry to save money.
Forgets to eat or shower during depressive episodes.
Stays up until 3am working on art or watching YouTube.
Leaves unread messages for days, then apologizes profusely.
Fidgets with jewelry or hoodie strings in public.
Writes long, vulnerable captions or threads about mental health.
Volunteers for mutual aid projects when able.
Avoids phone calls, prefers texting or DMs.
Takes public transit or bikes instead of driving.
Keeps a messy but creative living space—art supplies everywhere.
Wears headphones in public to avoid small talk.
Collects free zines and stickers from local shops.
Uses humor and memes to deflect from serious topics.
Suppresses emotions until overwhelmed, then has emotional outbursts.
Daydreams about alternative lives and careers.

morning: Wakes up between 9:30 and 11:00am, depending on sleep quality.
Checks phone immediately—social media, news, messages.
Makes coffee with oat milk, sometimes skips breakfast.
Listens to a podcast or lo-fi playlist while getting dressed.
Spends 10-15 minutes picking out shoes to match outfit.
Writes or sketches in a journal if feeling motivated.
workday: Applies to jobs online, often gets distracted by social media.
Works on freelance art commissions or personal projects.
Takes breaks to scroll TikTok or Twitter.
Preps simple vegan meals (rice bowls, salads, sandwiches).
Attends virtual meetings or workshops for mutual aid groups.
Runs errands on foot or by bus—always wears statement sneakers.
Visits local thrift stores or art supply shops, even if just to browse.
evening: Cooks dinner, sometimes with friends or chosen family.
Watches anime, indie films, or YouTube essays.
Chats with friends on Discord or group texts.
Draws or edits photos while listening to music.
Struggles to wind down—may experience insomnia or anxiety.
Reads webcomics or graphic novels in bed.
weekend: Attends art markets, protests, or open mics if energy allows.
Hosts or joins zine-making sessions with friends.
Volunteers at community events or food pantries.
Spends time alone to recharge—drawing, meditating, or cleaning.

health.physical: Generally healthy, but low energy and occasional headaches. Walks or bikes for transportation, but not athletic. Eats a mostly vegan diet, sometimes struggles to get enough protein or iron. No major chronic illnesses.
health.mental: Diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder and depression. Experiences frequent mood swings, insomnia, and periods of low motivation. Takes medication inconsistently due to cost and forgetfulness. Attends therapy when affordable, but often relies on peer support. Sometimes struggles to maintain basic self-care during depressive episodes. Open about mental health online, but feels shame about lack of progress.
health.other: Mild lactose intolerance. Sensitive to loud noises and crowded spaces. Occasionally experiences panic attacks in high-stress situations.

family.description: African American, social worker in Seattle. Supportive but worried about Kai's financial instability. Shares recipes and family stories over video calls.
Japanese American, software engineer. Lives in Seattle, less emotionally expressive but proud of Kai's creativity. Sends care packages with Japanese snacks.
High school student, non-binary, shares interests in anime and art. Close relationship, frequent texting and meme sharing.

friends.name: Jules
friends.description: Queer Black poet and roommate from college. Lives in Chicago, mutual support system. Collaborate on zines and attend open mics together.

friends.name: Mina
friends.description: Japanese American photographer, met through online art community. Long-distance friendship, exchange art critiques and care packages.

friends.name: Sam
friends.description: Latinx mutual aid organizer. Met at a protest, now close friends. Share resources and vent about activism burnout.

professional.name: Alex
professional.description: Freelance client, local musician. Hired Kai for album art and event flyers. Occasional collaborator.

professional.name: Jordan
professional.description: Former art professor, mentor figure. Provides portfolio feedback and career advice.

relationships.romantic: Single, has had a few short-term relationships (mostly queer, non-binary, or femme partners). Values independence and is wary of codependency. Occasionally uses dating apps but finds them draining.
relationships.community: Active in local queer and BIPOC art scenes, mutual aid groups, and online fandoms. Chosen family is as important as biological family.

other_facts: Born and raised in Seattle, moved to Chicago at 19 for college and a more vibrant queer community.
Celebrates a mix of holidays: Juneteenth, Obon, New Year's Day, and chosen family 'Friendsgiving.'
First memory of art is drawing manga characters with a parent at age 6.
Struggled with identity growing up—felt 'not enough' of any one culture.
Came out as non-binary at 17; family was supportive but needed time to adjust.
Has a tattoo of a paper crane and a Sankofa bird, symbolizing heritage and healing.
Favorite pair of shoes: limited-edition vegan Nike Air Max, bought secondhand after months of saving.
Once spent an entire rent check on art supplies and regretted it for weeks.
Keeps a box of letters and zines from friends as a source of comfort.
Lost a close friend to suicide in high school, which deeply impacted views on mental health.
Dreams of starting a queer, BIPOC-run art collective.
Has been misgendered in job interviews, leading to anxiety about professional spaces.
Volunteered as a peer counselor for LGBTQ+ youth during college.
Favorite comfort food: vegan curry udon, recipe from grandmother.
Has a recurring nightmare about being lost in a mall with no exits.
Once organized a pop-up art show in a laundromat.
Collects enamel pins from every city visited.
Has a complicated relationship with money—oscillates between scarcity mindset and impulsive spending.
Uses art as a way to process trauma and connect with others.
Feels most at home in liminal spaces—late-night diners, empty buses, rooftops.
Has a playlist for every mood, from 'anxious but hopeful' to 'ready to riot.'
Wants to learn how to skateboard but is afraid of falling.
Has a mild fear of elevators.
Once went viral on TikTok for a video about thrifted fashion.
Keeps a plant collection, but most are struggling due to inconsistent care.
Has a soft spot for stray animals, feeds neighborhood cats.
Wrote a zine about being multiracial and non-binary that was featured in a local library.
Feels guilty about not finishing college, but resents the student debt system.
Has a complicated relationship with food—sometimes stress eats, sometimes forgets to eat.
Finds solace in rain and overcast weather.
Has a favorite bench in a local park for sketching and people-watching.
Once tried to start a podcast but lost motivation after three episodes.
Uses humor and memes as a shield against vulnerability.
Feels both pride and pressure in being a 'first' in many spaces (first out non-binary person in family, first to move out of state).
Has a box of unfinished art projects labeled 'someday.'
Believes in the power of small acts of kindness—leaves encouraging notes in library books.
Is often mistaken for younger than actual age due to style and demeanor.
Has a complicated relationship with sleep—sometimes stays up for 36 hours, sometimes sleeps all day.
Finds it hard to ask for help, but is always willing to help others.
Feels most alive when collaborating with other creatives.
Has a recurring fantasy of living in a tiny house by the lake, surrounded by art and friends.
